#the goal is to display sales and services of salon stylists
#data: salon sales, services, commissions, etc.

```{r import-data-visualize}
library(tidyverse)
library(readxl)
Staff_Commission <- read_excel("~/Downloads/Staff_Commission.xlsx")
View(Staff_Commission)
#Plotting the Total Revenue generated by each hair stylist
Staff_Commission %>% 
  filter(ServiceTotals > 1) %>% #filtering out front desk staff
  ggplot(aes(x= StaffName, y= ServiceTotals)) + 
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=.5, fill="steel blue") + 
  labs(title="Service Totals of Stylists ($)") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, vjust=0.6))
#Reordering by totals would be a more intuitive viz
Staff_Commission %>% 
  filter(ServiceTotals > 1) %>% 
  mutate(Name = fct_relevel(StaffName, "Samantha", "Stephanie", "Taylor", "Leslie", "Alanna", "Courtney", "Becca")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x= Name, y= ServiceTotals)) + 
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=.5, alpha=.85, fill="steel blue") + 
  labs(title="Service Totals of Stylists", y = "Dollars", x = "Stylist") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, vjust=0.6)) 
  
#Additional plot based on the number of services without changing the stylist order
Staff_Commission %>% 
  filter(ServiceTotals > 1) %>% 
  mutate(Name = fct_relevel(StaffName, "Samantha", "Stephanie", "Taylor", "Leslie", "Alanna", "Courtney", "Becca")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x= Name, y= ServiceQty)) + 
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=.5, alpha=.65, fill="Red") + 
  labs(title="Service Totals of Stylists", y = "Dollars", x = "Stylist") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, vjust=0.6))
#Here we see that the number of services follows the same order as the service totals ($) except that Leslie is doing a roughly twice as many services as most of the others.
```
